appendix.title: &appshort; theme files
appendix.para: A theme UI file automates creation of widgets from an XML document, which generates the contents of a &layoutmanager; or a factory. The theme UI file also creates several supporting objects: dims, colors, and borders; as well as custom appearance objects.

informalexample.programlisting:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <theme version="1" xmlns:xi="http://www.w3.org/2003/XInclude">
<layout type="grid" id="main-window-grid">
<!-- ... -->
</layout>
<factory type="grid" id="button-row">
<!-- ... -->
</layout>
<layout type="book" id="formatting-options">
<!-- ... -->
</layout>
<factory type="book" id="formatting-generic-options">
<!-- ... -->
</layout> </theme>

appendix.para: The XML document's root widget is a theme element. For future compatibility, its version attribute should be 1. The theme element contains layout and factory elements. Their id attributes must be unique, and serve as means of referring to each layout and factory element by name. Only the first layout and factory with a unique id takes effect, second and subsequent layouts and factorys with the same id get ignored. In all other respects the relative order of layouts and factorys doesn't matter, and together with XInclude this makes it possible to implement to create a theme file with shared layouts and factorys, and then include it from other theme files, extending and/or overriding parts of it.
The theme file's XML document also contains several other elements, like dims, colors, borders, and appearance, with their own ids that work the same way.
The widget contents of layouts or a factorys depend on their type. The widget content effectively translates to invoking the corresponding methods of a &layoutmanager; or a &factory;:

varlistentry.term: layouts with a type of grid.

listitem.para: The widget contents of this layout invoke the corresponding methods of a grid layout manager.

varlistentry.term: layouts with a type of book.

listitem.para: The widget contents of this layout invoke the corresponding methods of a book layout manager.

varlistentry.term: factorys with a type of grid.

listitem.para: The widget contents of this layout invoke the corresponding methods of a grid factory.

varlistentry.term: factorys with a type of book.

listitem.para: The widget contents of this layout invoke the corresponding methods of a book page factory.

section.title: Creating generic widgets using named callbacks
section.para: Creating widgets using a theme file is a three step process:

listitem.para: create() an &ns;::w::const_uigenerators object. This loads the theme file and effectively compiles it into an internal representation, a reference-counted object. create() returns a &ns;::w::const_uigenerators handle, a reference to a const object object (the compiled theme file object remains constant after it's created).

Create an &ns;::w::uielements object. The &ns;::w::uielements gets created in automatic scope, and this individual object is no longer required after the widgets get generate()d. The &ns;::w::const_uigenerators contains multiple layout specifications, is constant, and can be used multiple times.

An &ns;::w::uielements servers a dual purpose. Its first member, factories is a map. The map key's is a text string, a label. The keys' values are lambdas, or callable objects. The lambdas receive a &factory; as their parameter. It's expected that each lambda uses the factory to create a single widget.
Invoke a layout manager's generate() to execute the compiled theme file, and create its contents.

A grid layout manager's generate() generates the contents of the contents of the layout manager from the theme file. The first parameter gives the name of a layout whose type must be grid, and have a matching id (main-window-grid, in this example). This executes the specification for this layout from the compiled theme file.

section.para: &ns;::w::uielements's second purpose is to store widgets and other object that generate() creates. &ns;::w::uielements's various methods return different kinds of objects created by generate().

section.title: Creating widgets directly from an XML theme file
section.para: It's always possible to create label widgets by specifying a named element in the theme file, and implementing the named &ns;::w::uielements callback when generating the widgets.

It is possible to create regular widgets directly from a specification in the XML theme file. uigenerator4.C gives an example of creating label widgets from the theme file. This example creates the same label widget wordwraplabel.C, but this approach makes it possible to tweak labels without recompiling the code.
The contents of the label is a &ns;::w::theme_text with references to colors and fonts defined in the theme file or the default display theme.

section.title: dims, colors, and borders
section.para: dimensions specify sizes of various UI elements, A dim element specifies a size in millimeters, which can be fractional, and calculates the number of pixels closest to the given size, taking into account the current theme's scale. This is the same as setting a &ns;::w::dim_arg from the given value. A special value of inf evaluates to a NAN, and used in contexts of specifying an unlimited maximum widget size.

colors define colors in terms of their red, ggreen, bblue, and aalpha (transparency) values. Each component ranges from 0 (none) to 1.0 (maximum intensity). This is the same as setting &ns;::w::color_arg from an &ns;::w::rgb whose values are scaled from 0 to &ns;::w::rgb::maximum with 1.0 as &ns;::w::rgb::maximum.
Other parts of the theme file refer to dimensions and colors by their ids:

A border element defines a border, effectively initializing a &ns;::w::border_arg from a &ns;::w::border_infomm.
The border contains the following elements:

listitem.para: This dimension sets &ns;::w::border_infomm's width.
This dimension sets &ns;::w::border_infomm's height.
This sets &ns;::w::border_infomm's rounded (an empty tag is equivalent to 1).
This dimension sets &ns;::w::border_infomm's hradius.
This dimension sets &ns;::w::border_infomm's vradius.
These elements' values set &ns;::w::border_infomm's corresponding members.
This colorension sets &ns;::w::border_infomm's color1. This is the border's primary color.
This colorension sets &ns;::w::border_infomm's color2. This is an optional secondary color for drawing dashed borders.
This element can appear more than once, and initializes &ns;::w::border_infomm's dashes. This creates a border that's drawn as a dashed line instead of a solid color.

section.title: Using dims, colors, and borders from the default theme
section.para: Like with all other elements, the relative order of dims, colors, and borders, relative to each other and other elements in the theme file, does not matter, except that the first unique id takes priority over other elements with the same id which get ignored.
ids that are not defined in the theme file are presumed to be referring to the ones specifies by the current default theme.

section.title: Derivedcolors, and borders
section.para: All theme files can reference the following colors: transparent, with 0 r, g, b, and a values, and the following standard HTML 3.2 colors: black, gray, silver, white, maroon, red, olive, yellow, green, lime, teal, aqua, navy, blue, fuchsia, purple.

informalexample.programlisting:
<color id="bgcolor" scale="gray" />
<color id="bgcolor2" scale="gray"> <r>1.2</r> </color>
<border id="dashed-border" from="solid-border">
<color>green</color> <color2>blue</color2> <dash>.75</dash> <rounded>1</rounded> </border>

section.para: Declaring a color with a scale attribute creates a new alias for another color in the theme file. This copies the r, g, b, and a values from the other color, and multiplies them by the values in the scaled alias, if specified. The above example creates a bgcolor2 from a bgcolor, with the red component multiplied by 1.2 (20% higher red channel). The scaled component values get automatically truncated to the range of 0 to 1.

Similarly, declaring a border with a from attribute creates a new border based on another border, with any given values replacing the values from the other border, with one exception: declaring a new color color replaces the color from the original border, and resets the new border's color2, unless the new border also specifies an explicit color2; and specifying the new border's color2 requires explicitly specifying its color, also.
An empty dash in a derived border removes the inherited dashes.

section.title: Gradient colors
section.para: Color gradients are allowed only for colors that are used as background colors of widgets. A background color gradient is a color that that transitions across its widget.

&appshort;'s gradient colors are directly implemented using the &render;'s CreateLinearGradient and CreateRadialGradient requests. &appshort; forms the &RENDER; request by translating and computing its values from a virtualized representation; from virtual coordinates. The following is a brief summary of the XML format that forms each request, and a brief description, see the &RENDER; specification for more information.

Gradient colors contain two or more gradients. values are non-negative integers, one of the values must be 0, and all values must be unique. The highest value sets the gradient's range, and each gradient specifies a color that references another plain color.

A linear_gradient type defines a gradient with a linear color transition to each color across a range of 0 to the maximum value. This is the same as setting &ns;::w::color_arg from an &ns;::w::linear_gradient. The above example creates a gradient that starts with the gray color, becomes a silver color at exactly the midpoint, and reaches the white color at the end.
Using values of 0, 3, 4 results in a linear gradient that transitions to the 3 color at about 75% of the way from the starting to the ending color value.

The gradient colors transition over virtual coordinates of (x1, y1) through (x2, y2). The coordinate (0, 0) is the upper-left corner of the widget. (1, 1) is the bottom-right corner. Specifying x1, y1, x2, and y2 is optional; and they default to (0, 0) and (1, 1); by default, a linear gradient transition from the upper-left corner to the bottom-right corner.

The virtual gradient range of (0, 0) to (1, 1) gets automatically scaled to the widget's size, so that (0, 0) is always the top-left corner, and (1, 1) is always the widget's bottom-right corner. Specifying widthmm, heightmm sets a fixed width or height, specified in millimeters, that gets used to compute the virtual gradient positions, instead of automatically adjusting them to the widget's actual size. This example creates a gradient for a size of 10x10 millimeters; (0, 0) is still the top-left corner and (1, 1) is 10 millimeters below and to the right of it. If the widget is larger, the additional space gets filled with the closest color from the computed gradient; a smaller widget results in a clipped gradient.

A negative widthmm or heightmm value anchors the gradient coordinates to the opposite border. A widthmm and heightmm of -10 results in a 10x10 millimeter gradient that's anchored at the widget's bottom-right corner.

A radial_gradient type also defines a gradient from a values of 0 to the maximum value. The radial gradiant also gets defined in a virtual coordinate range (0, 0) to (1, 1), and also based on two coordinates in the range, which are specified as (inner_x, inner_y) and (outer_x, outer_y).

inner_radius defines a circle whose center is (inner_x, inner_y) and outer_radius defines a circle whose center is (outer_x, outer_y). The actual radius value of 1 is defined by inner_radius_axis and outer_radius_axis, respectively. This is the same as setting &ns;::w::color_arg from an &ns;::w::radial_gradient.
The above example shows the default values for all these settings, if not specified.

The inner circle must be contained entirely within the outer circle. The color value of 0 forms the area inside the inner circle, and the color gradient transition accordingly, to the maximum color value that forms the area outside the outer circle.
Optional widthmm and heightmm values work the same way for radial gradient as they do for linear gradients.

section.title: Specifying &ns;::w::dim_axis_arg values
section.para: A &ns;::w::dim_axis_arg value is specified as three discrete dim elements:
Individual min, preferred, and max values set the minimum, preferred, and maximum values of a &ns;::w::dim_axis_arg by specifying ids of other dim elements in the theme file.

section.title: fonts
section.para: A font's id attribute gives the label that theme file uses to refer to this font. An optional from attribute specifies that this font specification is based on another font. The other font's definition gets copied, and this font's settings modify the original font's setting.
The font element contains the following elements:

listitem.para: foundry and family specify the system font.
point_size specifies the font's height in points.

note.para: Font sizes are approximate. The actual font size could slightly vary. Even an explicit pixel size may not produce a font with the given height. Some fonts' height can only scale to a small pixel multiple.

listitem.para: weight of thin, light, normal, medium, demibold, bold, heavy, or extrablack.
slant of roman, italic, or oblique.
width of condensed, normal, or expanded.
A font-specific style.
A spacing of proportional, dual, monospace, or charcell.

section.title: Other values in theme files
section.para: Values for various properties of &supportedthemewidget;s and appearance objects directly translate to the values of various &appshort; data types.

section.title: &ns;::w::halign values
section.para: An &ns;::w::halign value is one of: left, center, right, or fill.

section.title: &ns;::w::valign values
section.para: An &ns;::w::valign value is one of: top, middle, bottom, or fill.

section.title: &ns;::w::scrollbar_visibility values
section.para: An &ns;::w::scrollbar_visibility value is one of: never, always, automatic, or automatic_reserved.

section.title: &ns;::w::text_param values
section.para: The content of elements that specify values of &ns;::w::text_param fields is &ns;::w::theme_text-formatted text with references to colors and fonts defined in the theme file or the default display theme.

section.title: Using gettext with &ns;::w::text_param values
section.para: If the generator object has an optionally attached message catalog, each text label in the theme file gets looked up in the message catalog. The type attribute gets ignored when creating widget from the theme file, and it serves to mark translatable text in the theme file, such as the one in the label element. gettext tools know look only for translatable strings in C/C++ source, so &appshort; provides an XML stylesheet that creates a pseudo-C/C++ file that does not get compiled, but it contains translatable strings that gettext's msgfmt picks up and adds to the message catalog template.
The extract-theme-text.xsl file in &appshort;'s theme directory is a stylesheet that generates pseudo C/C++ source containing text from any element with a type="theme_text" in a theme file:
If theme.xml's contents include the above example, the resulting strings.C has the following contents:
This gets picked up by msgfmt and included with the rest of the application's translatable strings. &appshort; provides automake macros to automate this process. In the Makefile.am:
This creates Makefile rules that automatically build strings.C from theme.xml. The EXTRACT_THEME_TEXT_GEN macro comes from &appshort;'s @LIBCXXW_AM@ framework.

Specifying the optional &ns;::messages parameter, when creating a generator object, attaches a message catalog to the generator generator. The message catalog should explicitly use a UTF-8 &ns;::locale so that the translated messages get directly converted to Unicode.

section.title: &ns;::w::shortcut values
section.para: An &ns;::w::shortcut contains text that uses the same &ns;::w::theme_text formatting as &text_paramvalue;s, except fonts, colors, and other visual markup references are not allowed, of course. Keyboard shortcuts frequently associate with buttons and labels that have translatable text; with distinct ${context}s that discriminate different text. This allows the associated keyboard shortcuts also have translated text; and if the main button or label's text gets translated, the associated keyboard shortcut gets revised accordingly.

note.para: This means that a shortcut must use $$ to refer to the $ key.

section.para: The specified shortcut text selects the most appropriate &ns;::w::shortcut constructor: a single character, or one or more modifiers, like Ctrl or Alt, followed by a single character, or Fn (function key), or a recognized special key (like Left or Del).

section.title: &ns;::w::list_item_param values
section.para: List layout manager's methods that add new items to the selection list take a vector of &ns;::w::list_item_param values. These various variant values get specified as follows:

listitem.para: A selection list text value, specified as a &text_paramvalue;.
Specifies a selection list image icon value.
Inserts a list separator, a &ns;::w::separator value in the &ns;::w::list_item_paramvector.
Specifies a &keyboard_shortcutvalue;.
An inactive keyboard shortcut value.
Specifies an identation level of this list item in a hierarchical list:
Specifies an identifier for the following list item.
Specifies a menuoption menu attribute, in a type=menubar factorys that creates menu items.
Specifies a submenu menu attribute, in a type=menubar factorys that creates menu items. The following example in uigenerator6.C creates a Recent submenu:

submenu, like any other item attribute, must precede it's list item, in this case a Recent label. submenu contains an inner list of type=list layout elements; typically an append_items that defines the submenus's contents.

section.para: All &ns;::w::list_item_param values must follow the same relative ordering rules as actual &ns;::w::list_item_param values, specifically: all attributes of a list item (such as its keyboard shortcut or its hierarchy indentation value) must precede their label or the image list item value. This includes the name identifier. All attributes must precede the first label or the image list item value in a multi-column list.

section.title: List item names

informalexample.programlisting:
<items>
<name>option_1</name> <shortcut>Alt-1</shortcut> <label type="theme_text">Option1</label>
<separator />
<name>option_2</name> <shortcut>Alt-2</shortcut> <label type="theme_text">Option1</label>
</items>
&ns;::w::uielements elements;
layout->generate("main-window-grid", generator, elements);
&ns;::w::listitemhandle h=elements.get_listitemhandle("option_1");

section.para: A name element in a &listitemparamvalueslist; is not an actual &ns;::w::list_item_param value. This element assigns an identifer to the following list item. After generating the contents of a selection list, After the widgets get generated, get_element() retrieves a &ns;::w::listitemhandle for the new list item specified by its name.
name element values are optional, but if specified every item in a &listitemparamvalueslist; must have a name.

section.title: type=grid layouts

informalexample.programlisting:
<dim id="extra-padding">2.0</dim>
<layout type="grid" id="main-window-grid">
<halign> <col>0</col> <halign>left</halign> </halign>
<valign> <row>0</row> <valign>middle</valign> </valign>
<padding> <row>0</row> <side>left</side> <padding>extra-padding</padding> </padding> </layout>
<!-- in some factory... --> <container> <name>main-window-grid</name> <type>grid</type> </container>
&ns;::w::gridlayoutmanager glm=container->get_layoutmanager();
glm->generate("main-window-grid", generator, elements);

section.para: The contents of a layouts of type=grid specify the methods invoked by grid layout manager's generate().

section.title: Creating type=grid layouts
section.para: A container with a type=grid creates a container that uses the grid layout manager.
background_color invokes the grid layout manager's set_background_color() method.
remove_background_color invokes the grid layout manager's remove_background_color() method.
halign invokes the grid layout manager's col_alignment() method. The halign element contains an &halignvalue;.
valign invokes the grid layout manager's row_alignment() method. The valign element contains an &valignvalue;.
padding invokes the grid layout manager's row_top_padding(), row_bottom_padding(), col_left_padding(), or col_right_padding() method.

section.title: default_col_border and default_row_border
section.para: These elements invoke the grid layout manager's default_col_border()() or default_row_border()() method.
percent invokes the grid layout manager's requested_col_width() or requested_row_height() method.

section.title: remove_col_defaults and remove_row_defaults
section.para: These elements invoke the grid layout manager's remove_col_defaults() and remove_row_defaults() methods.

section.title: remove_all, remove_row, and remove_cell
section.para: These elements invoke the grid layout manager overloaded methods that remove all existing contents, a single row, or a single cell.

section.title: append_row, insert_row, append_columns, insert_columns, replace_row, and replace_cell
section.para: These methods create a new grid factory using the corresponding grid layout manager method; then use the referenced type=grid factory element to create new elements in the grid layout manager's container using the new grid factory.

section.title: type=grid factorys
section.para: The contents of a factorys of type=grid specify the methods invoked on a grid factory.
halign invokes the grid factory's halign() method. The halign element contains an &halignvalue;.
The valign invokes the grid factory's valign() method. The valign element contains an &valignvalue;.
padding invokes the grid factory's padding(), left_padding(), right_padding(), top_padding(), or bottom_padding() method. The side value is one of all, left, right, top, or bottom.
border invokes the grid factory's border(), left_border(), right_border(), top_border(), or bottom_border() method. The side value is one of all, left, right, top, or bottom.

section.title: colspan and rowspan
section.para: colspan and rowspan invoke the grid factory's colspan() and rowspan() methods, respectively.
remove_when_hidden invokes the grid factory's remove_when_hidden() method.

section.title: elements and containers
section.para: elements and containers use the factory to create a new &themewidgetorcontainer;.

section.title: type=book layouts

informalexample.programlisting:
<layout type="book" id="application-settings">
<!-- ... -->
</layout>
<!-- in some factory... -->
<container> <name>application-settings</name> <type>book</type> <config> <appearance>application-settings-appearance</appearance> </config> </container>
&ns;::w::booklayoutmanager glm=container->get_layoutmanager();
glm->generate("application-settings", generator, elements);

section.para: The contents of a layouts of type=book specify the methods invoked by book layout manager's generate().

section.title: Creating type=book layouts
section.para: A container with a type=book creates a container that uses the book layout manager. An optional config element sets non-default values of the &ns;::w::new_booklayoutmanager that creates the container:

listitem.para: Sets the book layout manager's appearance object.

section.title: append_pages and insert_pages

informalexample.programlisting:
<layout type="book" id="application-settings">
<!-- ... -->
<append_pages> <name>general-settings</name> </append_pages>
<append_pages> <name>process-settings</name> <pos>0</pos> </append_pages>
<!-- ... -->
</layout>
<factory type="book" id="general-settings">
<!-- ... -->
</factory>
<factory type="book" id="process-settings">
<!-- ... -->
</factory>

section.para: append_pages and insert_pages invoke the book layout manager's append() and insert() methods to create a new &ns;::w::bookpagefactory, then use the named type=book factory element to create new book pages.
remove invokes the book layout manager's remove() method.
open invokes the book layout manager's open() method.
close invokes the book layout manager's close() method.

section.title: type=book factorys
section.para: The contents of a factorys of type=book specify the methods invoked on a book page factory.
halign invokes the book page factory's halign() method. The halign element contains an &halignvalue;.
valign invokes the book page factory's valign() method. The valign element contains an &valignvalue;.
set_appearance invokes the book page factory's set_appearance() method. The appearance value gives the id of a type=bookpage appearance object.
add invokes the book page factory's add() method, creating a new tab and a page in the book container.
The tab element creates the page's tab, and must have exactly one &themewidgetorcontainer;. It's usually a plain label.
The page element creates the page itself, and must have exactly one &themewidgetorcontainer;. It is usually a &themecontainer;.
An optional shortcut element contains the page's &keyboard_shortcutvalue;.

section.title: type=list layouts
section.para: The contents of a layouts with type=list specify the list layout manager methods that get invoked to generate() its contents.

section.title: Creating type=list layouts
section.para: A container with a type=list creates a container that uses the list layout manager.
uigenerator5.C is an example of creating a list container using a theme file:

section.title: Initializing &ns;::w::new_listlayoutmanagers
section.para: An optional config element sets non-default values of the &ns;::w::new_listlayoutmanager that creates the container:

listitem.para: Sets the &ns;::w::new_listlayoutmanager's selection_type:
The value of a selection_type is one of: single, single_optional, multiple, or node.
This element invokes one of &ns;::w::new_listlayoutmanager's overloaded height() methods:
Specifies the list height in the range of a minimum and maximum number of rows, calculated using the default list font's height.
Invokes variable_height() method.
A height element with an &dimaxisargvalue; invokes height() with this explicit value.
Invokes one of &ns;::w::new_listlayoutmanager's methods that specifies the list's width:
This invokes the default_width() method.
This invokes the variable_width() method.
A width element with an &dimaxisargvalue; invokes width() with this explicit value.
Sets the &ns;::w::new_listlayoutmanager's columns value:
This sets columns to 2, creating a list with two columns.
Initializes &ns;::w::new_listlayoutmanager's requested_col_widths map:
Each requested_col_width contains a column number and a percentage value from 0 to 100.
Initializes &ns;::w::new_listlayoutmanager's col_alignments map:
Each col_alignment contains a column number and an halign &halignvalue;.
Initializes &ns;::w::new_listlayoutmanager's row_alignments map:
Each col_alignment contains a column number and an valign &valignvalue;.
Initializes &ns;::w::new_listlayoutmanager's column_border map:
Each column_border contains a column number and a border reference.
Initializes &ns;::w::new_listlayoutmanager's minimum_column_widths map:
Each minimum_column_width contains a column number and a width value.
Initializes &ns;::w::new_listlayoutmanager's synchronized_columns object:

All generate()d selection lists with the same synchronized_columns name have the same &ns;::w::synchronized_axis handle. The element's name is an opaque label. &ns;::w::synchronized_axis objects get automatically created, internally, and associated with their name.
Initializes &ns;::w::new_listlayoutmanager's lr_paddings map:
Each lr_padding contains a column number; and a left and right values that reference dim elements in the theme file.
These elements initialize the corresponding &ns;::w::new_listlayoutmanager members:
The horizontal_scrollbar and vertical_scrollbar elements contain &scrollbar_visibilityvalue;s.
Sets the &ns;::w::new_listlayoutmanager's appearance value:
The value of the element specifies an appearance object of type=list.

This configures the list (or a table) in a pane container. An optional synchronized flag indicates that the new list/table's columns are synchronized with another list/table in the same pane container.

section.title: append_items, replace_all_items, insert_items, and replace_items
section.para: append_items, replace_all_items, insert_items, and replace_items invoke the corresponding list layout manager methods that add new items to the list. The position value specifies the insert or replacement position (for insert_items and replace_items). The items element contains the &listitemparamvalueslist; which defines the new list items.

section.title: remove_item and remove_items
section.para: remove_item and remove_items invoke the corresponding list layout manager methods that remove items from an existing list. The position value specifies the position index of the element to remove; or the first element to remove, with remove_items, and a count giving the number of elements to remove.
autoselect invokes the list layout manager's autoselect() method, with the value of the position element giving its parameter.

append_copy_cut_paste invokes the list layout manager's append_copy_cut_paste() method, with the value of the parent element giving the value of the append_copy_cut_paste()'s parent element parameter.

parent's value is a name of an existing element in the element factory object that gets passed to generate(). uigenerator6.C gives an example of a typical implementation that stores the main window widget in the element factory object as the main element, and then specifying main for the parent element.

uigenerator6.C gives an example of retrieving the resulting &ns;::w::copy_cut_paste_menu_items object and installing a status update for the File menu, where the menu items appear, to update() their status each time the menu gets shown.

section.title: type=standard_combobox and type=editable_combobox and layouts
section.para: The contents of a layouts with type=standard_combobox or type=editable_combobox specify the standard or editable combo-box layout manager methods that get invoked to generate() its contents.

section.title: Creating type=standard_combobox and type=editable_combobox layouts
section.para: A container with a type=standard_combobox or type=editable_combobox creates a container that uses the corresponding combo-box layout manager.

section.title: Initializing &ns;::w::new_standard_comboboxlayoutmanager and &ns;::w::new_editable_comboboxlayoutmanager
section.para: An optional config element sets non-default values of the &ns;::w::new_listlayoutmanager or the &ns;::w::new_editable_comboboxlayoutmanager that creates the container:

listitem.para: Sets the selection_required flag to false:
Initializes the synchronized_columns object:

All generate()d combo-boxes with the same synchronized_columns name have the same &ns;::w::synchronized_axis handle. The element's name is an opaque label. &ns;::w::synchronized_axis objects get automatically created, internally, and associated with their name.
appearance sets &ns;::w::new_standard_comboboxlayoutmanager's or &ns;::w::new_editable_comboboxlayoutmanager's appearance value:
The value of the element specifies an appearance object of type=combobox.
An editable combo-box also has an input_appearance for its input field, referencing an type=input_field. appearance object.

section.title: type=standard_combobox and type=editable_combobox layout elements
section.para: type=standard_combobox and type=editable_combobox layout share the same elements as type=list layouts. The combo-box layout managers inherit from the list layout manager, and inherit the list layout manager's methods.

section.title: type=table layouts
section.para: The contents of a layouts with type=table specify the table layout manager methods that get invoked to generate() its contents.

section.title: Creating type=table layouts
section.para: A container with a type=table creates a container that uses the table layout manager.

section.title: Initializing &ns;::w::new_tablelayoutmanager
section.para: The config element initializes the &ns;::w::new_tablelayoutmanager that creates the container:

listitem.para: Sets the &ns;::w::new_tablelayoutmanager's table_width value:
Sets the &ns;::w::new_tablelayoutmanager's maximum_table_width value:
Invokes &ns;::w::new_tablelayoutmanager's unlimited_table_width() method.
This element sets &ns;::w::new_tablelayoutmanager's adjustable_column_widths to true.
Sets the &ns;::w::new_tablelayoutmanager's extra_table_appearance value:
The value of the element specifies an appearance object of type=table.
Calls &ns;::w::new_tablelayoutmanager's restore() method. The &ns;::w::uigenerator must get constructed with a &ns;::w::const_screen_positions parameter with preserved window positions.
The value of the element specifies the table's unique label that gets passed to its restore() method.

varlistentry.term: Inherited list layout manager initialization configuration

listitem.para: &ns;::w::new_tablelayoutmanager inherits from &ns;::w::new_listlayoutmanager, and all config values that initialize &ns;::w::new_listlayoutmanagers also appear in a type=table container's config.
Of particular importance is the columns value that sets the number of columns in the table.

section.para: A list of header values defines the contents of the table's header row. The internally-constructed &ns;::w::new_tablelayoutmanager's header_factory uses the headers to create the table's header widgets.
The number of header values must be equal to the table's columns value. Each header should create one &themewidget;. The usual table header theme widget is a plain label.

replace_header invokes the table layout manager. replace_header() method, with the value of the column element giving the value of the replace_header()'s parent element parameter. replace_header()'s returned &factory; gets used to create a &themewidget; as specified by the header element. The usual table header theme widget is a plain label.

section.title: append_items, replace_all_items, and other list layout manager methods
section.para: type=table layouts also contain all elements that appear in type=table layouts.

section.title: type=menubar layouts
section.para: The contents of a layouts of type=menubar specify the methods invoked by menu bar layout manager's generate():

informalexample.programlisting:
<layout type="menubar" id="mainmenubar"> <append_menus> <name>mainmenu</name> </append_menus> </layout>
<factory type="menubar" id="mainmenu">
<!-- ... -->
</factory>
// ....
main_window->get_menubarlayoutmanager() ->generate("mainmenubar", generator, elements);

section.para: Using a main window's get_menubarlayoutmanager() and invoking its generate() executes the instructions from the layouts of type=menubar. These layouts contain the following elements:

listitem.para: This is equivalent to invoking the corresponding &ns;::w::menubarlayoutmanager method to create a new &ns;::w::menubarfactory. The name specifies the id of a factory that generates the contents of the resulting &ns;::w::menubarfactory. The position element specifies the insertion position parameter (for insert_menus and insert_right_menus).
For completeness' sake, this is equivalent to invoking the corresponding &ns;::w::menubarlayoutmanager method to remove a menu from the menu bar.

varlistentry.para: The position element specifies which menu gets removed from the menu bar.

section.title: type=menubar factorys
section.para: The contents of a factorys of type=menubar specify the &ns;::w::menubarfactory methods that get invoked when generating the contents of a menu bar.
uigenerator6.C gives an example of using a menu bar factory to create its menus from uigenerator6.xml:

section.title: Adding menus
section.para: add in a factorys of type=menubar create a new menu, and must have a title and a menu element.
title sets the new menu's title, and contains any element that's valid in a generic factory. The traditional menu title is a label element.
The menu element contains type=list layout elements.

In the general case, it's typically a single append_items element, specifying a name of each menuitem. uigenerator6.xml provides an example of generate()ing a menu and then using get_list_itemhandle to retrive a &ns;::w::listitemhandle for each named menu itema and installing a &callback; that gets invoked by selecting the menu item.

section.title: type=pane layouts

informalexample.programlisting:
<layout type="pane" id="mainpane"> <append_panes> <name>mainpanecontents</name> </append_panes> </layout>
<factory type="pane" id="maincontents">
<!-- ... -->
</factory>
// ....
&ns;::w::panelayoutmanager plm=container->get_layoutmanager();
plm->generate("mainpane", generator, elements);

section.para: The contents of a layouts with type=pane specify the pane layout manager methods that get invoked to generate() its contents.

section.title: Creating type=pane layouts
section.para: A container with a type=pane creates a container that uses the pane layout manager.

section.title: Initializing &ns;::w::new_panelayoutmanager
section.para: The config element initializes the &ns;::w::new_panelayoutmanager that creates the container:

listitem.para: These elements reference other dims in the theme file, defining the size of the pane container.
This is equivalent to specifying the same minimum_size, preferred_size, and maximum_size.
Invokes the corresponding &ns;::w::new_panelayoutmanager method.
Sets the &ns;::w::new_panelayoutmanager's appearance value:
Calls &ns;::w::new_panelayoutmanager's restore() method. The &ns;::w::uigenerator must get constructed with a &ns;::w::const_screen_positions parameter with preserved window positions.
The value of the element specifies the pane container's unique label that gets passed to its restore() method.

section.title: append_panes, insert_panes, replace_panes, remove_pane, remove_all_panes, and replace_all_panes
section.para:
This is equivalent to invoking the corresponding &ns;::w::panelayoutmanager method to modify the contents of the pane container.
append_panes, insert_panes replace_panes, and replace_all_panes have a name value that specifies the id of a factory that generates the contents of the resulting &ns;::w::panefactory. The position element specifies the insertion position parameter (for insert_panes) or the removal positional parameter (for remove_pane).

section.title: type=pane factorys
section.para: The contents of a factorys of type=pane specify the &ns;::w::panefactory methods that get invoked when generating the contents of a pane container:

listitem.para: Sets the &ns;::w::panefactory's appearance value:
The value of the element specifies an appearance object of type=pane.

varlistentry.term: configure_for_new_list and inherited generic factory methods

informalexample.programlisting:
<factory type="pane" id="maincontents">
<configure_for_new_list />
<container> <type>list</type> <name>inventory</name> <config> <columns>2</columns> <synchronized_columns>stock</synchronized_columns> <configure_for_pane> <synchronized /> </configure_for_pane> </config> </container>
<configure_for_new_list />
<container> <type>list</type> <name>on_order</name> <config> <columns>2</columns> <synchronized_columns>stock</synchronized_columns> <configure_for_pane> <synchronized /> </configure_for_pane> </config> </container>
</factory>
<layout type="list" id="inventory">
<!-- ... -->
</layout>
<layout type="list" id="on_order">
<!-- ... -->
</layout>

listitem.para: A pane factory element contains any element that's valid in a generic factory. This creates a new pane. The new element is usually a container.

configure_for_new_list enables the integrated appearance of lists and tables in panes. A configure_for_new_list in a pane factory followed by a list container whose config has a configure_for_pane is equivalent to using pane factory's configure_new_list() when creating the new list or table.

section.title: element and container elements
section.para:
An element with a name (a named element) invokes the named callback from the &ns;::w::uielements parameter to generate().
This callback receives an &ns;::w::factory parameter which gets used, presumably, to create a widget. The first member of the &ns;::w::uielements object is map. The map's key is a std::string, and the name value gives the callback's key value. An exception gets thrown if the name key does not exist.
It's possible that the same name value appears more than once, in the same or different factorys. Each occurence of a name results in the callback getting invoked.

informalexample.programlisting:
<element id="fixed-canvas" tooltip="canvas-tooltip">

    ...

</element>

<container>
    <type>grid</type>
    <name>bottom-container</name>
</container>

<!-- ... -->

<layout type="grid" id="bottom-container">

<!-- ... -->

</layout>





/* ----- */
&ns;::w::uielements elements;

layout_manager->generate("dialog", generators, elements);

&ns;::w::canvas fixed_canvas=elements.get_element("fixed-canvas");

&ns;::w::container bottom_container=elements.get_element("bottom-container");

section.para: An element without a name creates one of several supported widgets directly, without invoking an application callback, using the given parameters. Supported widgets:

listitem.para: &ns;::w::labels
&ns;::w::canvases
&ns;::w::focusable_labels
&ns;::w::buttons
&ns;::w::input_fields
&ns;::w::date_input_fields
Checkbox &ns;::w::image_buttons
Radio &ns;::w::image_buttons
&ns;::w::progressbars
&ns;::w::color_pickers
&ns;::w::font_pickers
&ns;::w::scrollbars

section.para: These element elements have an optional id attribute. After the widgets get generated, &ns;::w::uielements's get_element() retrieves the created widget with the specified id. Duplicate ids get ignored; get_element() returns the first widget with the specified id.
These elements have an optional tooltip attribute that creates a tooltip for the widget and an optional context that creates a context popup menu for the widget.
A container creates a new &container; widget. Its name serves a dual purpose:

listitem.para: It gives the layout with the same id as the container's name. The types must match. This specifies the new &container;'s layout and creates the widget in the &container;.
After generate()ing the widgets, get_element() returns the created &ns;::w::container.

section.para: container creates a &container; and then generate()s the new container from another layout in the theme file, whose id is name. type must be either grid or book, and must match the layout's type.

container is equivalent to invoking the name-d element callback, and having the callback create a new container with the appropriate &layoutmanager;, and then generate()ing its contents from the layout specified by the name value (which serves the same dual purpose as the element element).
A container element also has other optional values that depend on its type that initialize the container.

section.title: Creating tooltips

informalexample.programlisting:
<element id="fixed-canvas" tooltip="canvas-tooltip">
...
</element>
<tooltip type="label" id="canvas-tooltip"> <label type='theme_text'>Click to adjust this color channel
(in the currently selected color)</label> </tooltip>

section.para: tooltips have unique ids. The second and subsequent tooltips with the same id get ignored. type must always be label, this is currently ignored but should be set for future extensibility.
elements' tooltip attribute refers to a tooltip with the given id. More then one element may refer to the same tooltip.

note.para: Only &supportedthemewidget;s have a tooltip attribute; &namedwidget;s are under the callbacks' control and only the callbacks can set their tooltips.

section.para: tooltips' contents are the same as label widget's label. This is equivalent to using a widget's create_tooltip() to create a basic, label tooltip.

section.title: Creating context popup menus
section.para: All &supportedthemewidget;s have an optional context element that uses create_popup_menu() to create a context popup menu. Its menu element generates the list layout manager for the context popup menu. An optional shortcut contains a &keyboard_shortcutvalue;.

An append_copy_cut_paste in the popup menu adds standard Copy, Cut, and Paste menu items. Its parent should be its element's id. The context popup automatically takes care of update()ing these menu items before the popup gets shown. It is not necessary to add the code for that, like for Copy, Cut, and Paste in the main application menu.

section.title: Label element widgets
section.para: Specifying an element that contains a label creates a new &themewidget; which is an &ns;::w::label widget. This is equivalent to invoking the &factory;'s create_label() method.
The contents of the label is a &text_paramvalue;.

section.title: Specifying label options
section.para: An optional options element of a label element specifies the values of a &ns;::w::label_config for creating the label widget.

section.title: Canvas element widgets
section.para: Specifying an element that contains a canvas creates a new &themewidget; which is an &ns;::w::canvas widget. This is equivalent to invoking the &factory;'s create_canvas() method.
The contents of the canvas set the values of create_canvas()'s &ns;::w::canvas_config parameter:

listitem.para: References a color in the theme file, defining the canvas's background color.

varlistentry.term: minimum_width, preferred_width, maximum_width, minimum_height, preferred_height, and maximum_height

listitem.para: These elements reference other dims in the theme file, defining the canvas's size.
This is equivalent to defining the same minimum, preferred, and maximum width.
This is equivalent to defining the same minimum, preferred, and maximum height.

section.title: Focusable label element widgets
section.para: Specifying an element with a focusable_label creates a new &themewidget; which is an &ns;::w::focusable_label widget. This is equivalent to invoking the &factory;'s create_focusable_label() method.

The focusable_label element has the same contents as a label element, with an additional options setting. options initializes the &ns;::w::focusable_label_config parameter for create_focusable_label, which has the same members as label's &ns;::w::label_config, with an additional focus_border that sets the focusable label's appearance object.

section.title: Button element widgets
section.para: Specifying an element with a button creates a new &themewidget; which is an &ns;::w::button widget. This is equivalent to invoking the &factory;'s create_button() method.
The button contains a &themewidgetorcontainer; that creates the contents of the button, usually a label element.
An optional config value sets create_button()'s &ns;::w::button_config parameter, and an optional shortcut contains the button's &keyboard_shortcutvalue;.

section.title: Input field element widgets
section.para: Specifying an element with a input_field creates a new &themewidget; which is an &ns;::w::input_field widget. This is equivalent to invoking the &factory;'s create_input_field() method.
The value of the input_field sets the initial contents of the input field (the first parameter to create_input_field()). It may be empty:

note.para: input_field element's value is a &text_paramvalue;, the first parameter to create_input_field(); this sets the input field's initial contents (fonts, colors, and other visual markup references are not allowed, of course, and any literal $ should be doubled as $$).

section.para: An optional config element initializes the &ns;::w::input_field_config parameter for create_input_field, as follows:

listitem.para: Sets the corresponding members in the &ns;::w::input_field_config parameter.
Sets the corresponding flags in the &ns;::w::input_field_config parameter.
Sets &ns;::w::input_field_config's update_clipboards to false.
Sets the &ns;::w::input_field_config's hint &text_paramvalue;.
Invokes &ns;::w::input_field_config's set_password() method, configuring this input field as a password input field.
Invokes &ns;::w::input_field_config's set_default_spin_control_factories() method, enabling this input field's spin buttons.
Invokes &ns;::w::input_field_config's enable_search() method, enabling this input field's search popup.
This element contains an &scrollbar_visibilityvalue; that sets the corresponding member of ths &ns;::w::input_field_config parameter.
This element contains an &halignvalue; that sets the corresponding member of ths &ns;::w::input_field_config parameter.
Sets the input field's appearance object.

section.title: Date input field element widgets

informalexample.programlisting: <element id="starting_date"> <date_input_field /> <config> <invalid_input type='theme_text'>Starting date is not valid</invalid_input> </config> </element>

section.para: Specifying an element with a date_input_field creates a new &themewidget; which is an &ns;::w::date_input_field widget. This is equivalent to invoking the &factory;'s create_date_input_field() method.
An optional config element initializes the &ns;::w::date_input_field_config parameter for create_date_input_field, as follows:

listitem.para: Sets the &ns;::w::date_input_field_config's invalid_input &text_paramvalue;.
Sets the date input field's appearance object.

section.title: Image element widgets
section.para: Specifying an element with a image creates a new &themewidget; which is an &ns;::w::image widget. This is equivalent to invoking the &factory;'s create_image() method.

The value of the image element is the first parameter to create_image(), the image file. The values of optional width and height elements are ids of dims in the them file. They are only used when the image is an &sxg; file and specifies the size the &sxg; image gets scaled to.

section.title: Checkbox element widgets
section.para: Specifying an element with a checkbox creates a new &themewidget; which is an &ns;::w::image_button checkbox widget. This is equivalent to invoking the &factory;'s create_checkbox() method.
The checkbox contains a &themewidgetorcontainer; that creates the contents of the checkbox, usually a label element.

An optional appearance value provides create_checkbox()'s optional &ns;::w::const_image_button_appearance parameter. The value of the appearance element is a type=image_button appearance object from the theme file.

section.title: Radio element widgets
section.para: Specifying an element with a radio creates a new &themewidget; which is an &ns;::w::image_button radio button widget. This is equivalent to invoking the &factory;'s create_radio() method.
The radio element contains a &themewidgetorcontainer; that creates the contents of the radio button, usually a label element.

An optional appearance value provides create_checkbox()'s optional &ns;::w::const_image_button_appearance parameter. The value of the appearance element is a type=image_button appearance object from the theme file.

The required group element sets the first parameter create_radio(), and gives the radio button group's name. All generate()d radio buttons with the same group name get created with the same &ns;::w::radio_group handle.

section.title: Progress bar element widgets

informalexample.programlisting:
<element id="progressbar"> <progressbar>progressbar_label_layout</progressbar> <type>grid</type> <config> <value>25</value> <maximum_value>50</maximum_value> <appearance>custom_progressbar</appearance> </config> </element>
<!-- ...... -->
<layout id="progressbar_label_layout" type="grid"> <append_row> <name>progressbar_label_row</name> </append_row> </layout>
<factory id="progressbar_label_row" type="grid"> <halign> <halign>center</halign> </halign> <element id="progressbar_label"> <label>25%</label> </element> </factory>
<!-- ...... -->
<appearance id="custom_progressbar" type="progressbar">
</appearance>

section.para: Specifying an element with a progressbar creates a new &themewidget; which is an &ns;::w::progressbar widget. This is equivalent to invoking the &factory;'s create_progressbar() method.

The progressbar element's value must be an id with a matching type of a layout which generates the initial layout of the progress bar's contents. This is typically a grid layout containing a centered label widget.
An optional config value initializes create_progressbar's &ns;::w::progressbar_config parameter.

section.title: Color picker element widgets
section.para: Specifying an element with a color_picker creates a new &themewidget; which is an &ns;::w::color_picker widget. This is equivalent to invoking the &factory;'s create_color_picker() method.
An optional config value initializes create_color_picker's &ns;::w::color_picker_config parameter, as follows:

listitem.para: Sets the &ns;::w::color_picker_config's initial_color. The value of the initial_color element is an id of a color. The referenced color must be a plain RGBA color specification.

Calls &ns;::w::color_picker_config's restore() method. The element must have a specified id, and the &ns;::w::uigenerator must get constructed with a &ns;::w::const_screen_positions parameter with preserved window positions.
Sets the color picker's appearance appearance object.

section.title: Font picker element widgets
section.para: Specifying an element with a font_picker creates a new &themewidget; which is an &ns;::w::font_picker widget. This is equivalent to invoking the &factory;'s create_font_picker() method.
An optional config value initializes create_font_picker's &ns;::w::font_picker_config parameter, as follows:

listitem.para: Sets the &ns;::w::font_picker_config's initial_font. The value of the initial_font element is an id of a font.
This &text_paramvalue; sets &ns;::w::font_picker_config's ok_label.
This &text_paramvalue; sets &ns;::w::font_picker_config's cancel_label.
This sets &ns;::w::font_picker_config's selection_required setting to false.
This sets &ns;::w::font_picker_config's select_by_foundry setting to true.
This sets &ns;::w::font_picker_config's foundry_required setting to true.

Calls &ns;::w::font_picker_config's restore() method. The element must have a specified id, and the &ns;::w::uigenerator must get constructed with a &ns;::w::const_screen_positions parameter with preserved window positions.
Sets the font picker's appearance appearance object.

section.title: Scroll-bar element widgets
section.para: Specifying an element with a scrollbar creates a new &themewidget; which is an &ns;::w::scrollbar widget. scrollbar's value is either horizontal or vertical, and this is equivalent to invoking the &factory;'s create_horizontal_scrollbar() or create_vertical_scrollbar() method.
An optional config value initializes the &ns;::w::scrollbar_config parameter, as follows:

listitem.para: Sets the &ns;::w::scrollbar_config's minimum_size. The value of the minimum_size element is an id of a dim.
These elements set &ns;::w::scrollbar_config's corresponding values.

section.para: An optional appearance element sets the optional appearance object parameter to create_horizontal_scrollbar() or create_vertical_scrollbar().

section.title: appearances

caption.para: Each appearance creates a custom &appearance_object;. uigenerator3.C creates a checkbox with a custom visual appearance. The default checkbox image gets replaced with a chevron that alternates between pointing left and right, with a large, blocky input focus frame around it.

section.para: Each appearance must have a unique id and a valid type. The first occurence of an appearance with a designated id takes effect, and subsequent appearances with the same id get ignored.

section.title: Contents of appearances in theme files
section.para: Each appearance contains elements whose names match the names of the fields in the corresponding appearance classes. A focus border appearance object contains two fields, focusoff_border, and focuson_border, and an appearance with a focus_border type specifies their values accordingly.
If not explicitly specified, the value of each field comes from the parent appearance, explicitly specified by the from attribute, or the default parent.
The fields get specified as follows:

listitem.para: std::string values get specified directly.

&ns;::w::border_arg values are are ids of borders in the theme file. They may also reference border ids from the current display theme, but this is not documented. A more future-proof way of borrowing a standard theme border is to use one of the built-in theme appearance objects as the parent object and not changing the existing &ns;::w::border_arg value.

Color values are are ids of colors in the theme file. They may also reference border ids from the current display theme, but this is not documented. A more future-proof way of borrowing a standard theme border is to use one of the built-in theme appearance objects as the parent object and not changing the existing color value.
Color values may also reference standard HTML 3.2 colors.

&ns;::w::dim_arg values are are ids of dims in the theme file. They may also reference border ids from the current display theme, but this is not documented. A more future-proof way of borrowing a standard theme border is to use one of the built-in theme appearance objects as the parent object and not changing the existing &ns;::w::dim_arg value.

&ns;::w::font_arg values are are ids of fonts in the theme file. They may also reference border ids from the current display theme, but this is not documented. A more future-proof way of borrowing a standard theme border is to use one of the built-in theme appearance objects as the parent object and not changing the existing &ns;::w::font_arg value.
See for more information on how to define custom fonts.
These fields contain &halignvalue;s.
These elements contain &scrollbar_visibilityvalue;s.
These fields contain &text_paramvalue;s.
These fields contain &valignvalue;s.

varlistentry.para: Appearance object can contain other appearance objects, as their fields. Example: the focus_border field in an image button appearance object is a focus border appearance object. The value of this field ia an ids of another appearance element, with the appropriate type, in the theme file.

section.title: std::optional and std::vector fields
section.para: A new appearance element starts with the values of all fields copied from its parent appearance object, then each value in the appearance element replaces the value of the corresponding field in the new appearance object. Some fields in appearance objects are std::optional or std::vectors. Each value of a std::vector field gets appended to a vector. Specifying a reset for a std::vector value erase()s its existing contents. Specifying a reset for a std::optional reset()s its value.
New values of a std::vector usually gets specified after reseting the values it inherited from its parent appearance object.
